newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai sugar firmer, more China offtake seen.
newsitem.headline: Thai sugar firmer, more China offtake seen.

text.p: Thai sugar premiums were slightly higher this week as the market expected more buying by China on the back of strong whites premiums, trade sources said on Friday.
Raws premiums for May/July deliveries were quoted around 0.55/0.65 cents/pound (bid/offer) over New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange (CSCE) futures on an FOB basis.
July/September deliveries were quoted at 0.50-0.60 cents/ pound over New York.
May whites premiums were quoted around $17 per tonne over London futures, traders said.
"With white-to-raw premium rising to almost $100 per tonne. China is expected to speed up its tolling," said one Thai shipper.
"Now that Thailand has no more white sugar left in stock, prices go up. Some of us watch China sell at such strong premiums with tears in the eyes," he said.
Thailand sold out of white sugar earlier in the season because of strong demand, mostly from Indonesia.
But some said premiums firmed also because some trading houses were chasing the prices up.
"The premiums are expected to continue to firm near-term. But there is no strong fundamentals or foreseeable new leads that would sustain it," said a trader from a leading Japanese trading firm.
One vessel was at a port loading 14,000 tonnes of raw sugar for China while three others were scheduled to arrive later this month for deliveries to the same destination.
According to trade industry estimates, the balance of sugar that has not been exported this season could reach one million tonnes.
The 1996/97 crushing season has ended, with only seven out of 46 mills still open. White sugar produced in this period is for the domestic quota and not for exports.
Preliminary figures from the industry ministry showed that 56.19 million tonnes of sugar cane were crushed as of May 14 against 57.26 million in the same period a year ago.
Sugar output so far has totalled 5.78 million tonnes tel quel against 5.98 million during the corresponding period last year.
Thailand's sugar exports in January-April were estimated at 2.14 million tonnes tel quel, a sharp drop from 2.73 million tonnes during the same period last year, according to independent surveyors.
